deliberation: Looked for metaphors, personifications, and idioms in the prophetic introduction. The formula 'the word of YHWH came to me' uses a motion verb with an abstract noun, which is a conventional idiom grounded in a personifying/metaphorical image of God's message as an arriving entity.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me
ground: an externally initiated encounter that reaches the prophet
onset and impact of an experience
human experience of receiving messages
instances.explanation: God’s message is depicted as a concrete entity that ‘comes’ to the prophet, personifying the divine word and using spatial-motion imagery for revelation.

deliberation: Checked the vocative 'son of man' and the command to prophesy; these are straightforward. The phrase 'set your face toward the Ammonites' is a bodily-orientation idiom/metaphor for directing prophetic attention and hostility.

instances.english_text: set your face toward the Ammonites
target: Ezekiel’s prophetic focus and stance against Ammon
ground: what you face is what you confront or address
direction of the body reflects focus and opposition
embodied cognition of attention as orientation
instances.explanation: Physical orientation of the face is used metaphorically/idiomatically for adopting a posture of focused confrontation toward Ammon.

deliberation: Reviewed the reported taunt over sanctuary, land, and exile. The interjection 'Aha' is emotional but not figurative. The key non-literal expression is 'House of Judah', a standard metonymy for the people/kingdom of Judah rather than an actual building.

instances.english_text: the House of Judah
target: the people and kingdom of Judah
ground: a house contains and represents its family or dynasty
physical structure stands for those belonging to it
common use of dwelling imagery for lineage and polity
posture: neutral naming within a judgment speech
instances.explanation: The term 'House of Judah' uses a building/household to stand metonymically for the people and polity of Judah.

deliberation: Considered whether deliverance to the 'sons of the east' and their encampments is figurative; it can be literal conquest imagery. The phrase about eating 'your fruit' and drinking 'your milk' uses specific agricultural products as a synecdoche/metonymy for all of Ammon’s resources.

instances.hebrew_text: הֵמָּה יֹאכְלוּ פִרְיֵךְ וְהֵמָּה יִשְׁתּוּ חֲלָבֵךְ
instances.english_text: they shall eat your produce and they shall drink your milk
vehicle: fruit and milk consumed by conquerors
ground: key foodstuffs represent the total yield of the land
part of agricultural output stands for the whole economy
synecdochic use of staple goods for all resources
instances.explanation: ‘Fruit’ and ‘milk’ function as a synecdoche for all the economic benefits of Ammon that invaders will consume.

deliberation: Checked whether the images of camels and sheep are purely literal or function as desolation imagery. Turning a capital city and a people into animal pastures is a standard metaphor for their complete ruin and depopulation, so I treat Rabbah and Ammon-as-a-whole as targets of desolation metaphors.

instances.english_text: I will make Rabbah a pasture for camels
target: the city of Rabbah in its future ruined state
vehicle: a pasture or habitation for camels
ground: a ruined, emptied city resembles open ground usable only by animals
loss of human habitation signaled by animal occupation
association of desolation with wilderness pastures
posture: judgmental portrayal of humiliation and ruin
instances.explanation: Rabbah’s coming desolation is pictured as its becoming nothing more than a camel pasture, a metaphor for total ruin and loss of urban life.

instances.english_text: and Ammon a place for sheep to lie down
target: the territory and people of Ammon in their future state
ground: a once-settled land reduced to serving only as animal rest-area signifies devastation
contrast between former inhabited nation and mere grazing/rest land
humiliation through pastoral imagery
instances.explanation: Ammon’s future condition is portrayed as nothing more than a sheep-resting ground, a metaphor for its complete desolation and loss of status.

deliberation: Evaluated the description of clapping hands, stamping feet, and rejoicing. These gestures may have been literal but are used representatively for inner contempt, making them gesture-metonymies/idiomatic for gloating hostility rather than just neutral actions.

instances.english_text: Because you clapped your hands and stamped your feet
target: Ammon’s rejoicing and contempt over Israel’s misfortune
vehicle: the physical acts of hand-clapping and foot-stamping
ground: specific gestures stand for and reveal inner scorn and gloating
visible actions metonymically express emotional attitude
common cultural link between such gestures and derision
instances.explanation: The gestures of clapping and stamping function metonymically and idiomatically to represent Ammon’s gloating contempt over Israel’s land.

deliberation: Checked several violent expressions. 'Stretching out my hand' is a standard anthropomorphic metaphor for divine action in judgment. 'Wiping you out from among the countries' uses spatial-removal imagery for extermination, distinct from the hand metaphor.

instances.english_text: I will stretch out My hand against you
target: YHWH’s act of bringing judgment on Ammon
vehicle: a person stretching out a hand against an enemy
human act of initiating a physical strike
ground: extending the hand is the prelude to striking or seizing
human aggression used to conceptualize divine action
shared sense of active, forceful engagement
instances.explanation: God’s judgment is portrayed in human-warrior terms as stretching out a hand to attack, a metaphorical anthropomorphism.

instances.english_text: I will wipe you out from among the countries
target: Ammon’s existence as a people among the nations
vehicle: removing/wiping something away from a place
erasure of a physical object from a surface or area
ground: to utterly destroy is likened to erasing something from a region
loss of political presence conceptualized as removal from a map
association of non-existence with being wiped away
instances.explanation: The threat to destroy Ammon uses the metaphor of being ‘wiped out’ from among the lands, an erasure image that hyperbolically expresses total removal.

deliberation: Moab and Seir’s statement is largely literal evaluation. The comparison 'like all the nations' is a straightforward claim of sameness, not a poetic simile. The expression 'House of Judah' again functions as a metonymy for the people/nation.

instances.english_text: the House of Judah
vehicle: dwelling that represents a family or dynasty
ground: a house stands for the family or dynasty it shelters
built structure used to designate social group
metonymic link between domicile and its occupants
instances.explanation: Again, 'House of Judah' uses a house as metonymy for the Judahite people and polity.

deliberation: Examined 'opening the shoulder of Moab' and 'the glory of the land'. 'Shoulder/flank of Moab' is an anatomical metaphor for the vulnerable side/border of the land being laid bare. 'The glory/beauty of the land' for the list of towns is another metaphor, personifying the towns as the land’s splendor.

instances.english_text: I will lay bare the flank [shoulder] of Moab
target: Moab’s border regions and fortified cities
vehicle: the 'shoulder/flank' of a body being opened or exposed
ground: as a bared flank exposes a person to attack, so opened borders expose a land
vulnerability and exposure conceptualized via bodily side
shared notion of protective outer side being breached
instances.explanation: Moab’s borders and cities are depicted as a bodily 'flank' that God will open, an anatomical metaphor for exposing the country to invasion.

instances.english_text: the glory [beauty] of the country
target: the named Moabite cities (Beth-jeshimoth, Baal-meon, Kiriathaim)
vehicle: the 'beauty' or 'glory' of a land (lit. gazelle-like splendor)
ground: these cities epitomize what is splendid in the land
most attractive part used to characterize the whole territory
association of prime locations with beauty and honor
posture: emphasis on the impressiveness of what will be struck
instances.explanation: The principal Moabite cities are called the 'glory of the land', a metaphor that personifies the land as possessing visible splendor concentrated in these towns.

deliberation: The transfer to the 'sons of the east' is military-political and can be literal. The statement that the sons of Ammon will not be remembered among the nations uses memory-erasure imagery and is rhetorically hyperbolic for total removal from the international scene.

instances.english_text: Thus Ammon shall not be remembered among the nations
target: Ammon’s continued existence and significance as a nation
vehicle: being (or not being) remembered in the minds of people
presence or absence in collective memory
ground: ceasing to exist or matter is likened to being erased from memory
political extinction conceptualized as total forgetfulness
shared notion that what no one remembers effectively does not count
instances.explanation: Ammon’s destruction is depicted as its no longer being 'remembered among the nations', a metaphorical and hyperbolic way of expressing total removal from the international stage.

deliberation: Surveyed 'I will execute judgments in Moab' and 'they shall know that I am YHWH'. Both are standard legal and theological formulations and can be taken straightforwardly; they do not rely on a distinct imaginative image beyond conventional legal terminology.

Reviewed the verse for figurative devices. 'Acted vengefully', 'wreaking revenge', and 'incurred guilt' are legal-moral descriptions without an obvious metaphor beyond ordinary legal language, and no clear similes, personifications, or merisms are present.

Again 'stretch out my hand' is the usual anthropomorphic metaphor for divine judgment. The phrase 'they shall fall by the sword' is an idiom where 'sword' stands metonymically for warfare and 'fall' euphemistically denotes death in battle.

instances.english_text: I will stretch out My hand against Edom
vehicle: stretching out a hand to strike or seize
offensive action by a human warrior
ground: both depict an initiating, forceful attack
God’s action is conceptualized through a human-warrior movement
shared sense of deliberate, aggressive engagement
instances.explanation: YHWH’s judgment on Edom is pictured as a human-like stretching out of the hand in attack, an anthropomorphic metaphor for divine action.

instances.english_text: they shall fall by the sword
target: the people of Edom from Tema to Dedan who will die in war
vehicle: being struck down by a weapon
ground: death in battle is conceptualized as 'falling' to a weapon
the sword stands metonymically for warfare as a whole
shared association between weapons and violent death
instances.explanation: The idiom 'fall by the sword' uses 'sword' as metonymy for warfare and 'fall' as a figurative way to speak of dying in battle.

deliberation: Looked for non-literal constructions. The central idiom is 'I will put my vengeance in Edom in the hand of my people Israel' (rendered 'through My people Israel'), which treats vengeance as a transferable object and 'hand' as a metonym for agency/instrument.

instances.hebrew_text: וְנָתַתִּי אֶת־נִקְמָתִי בֶּאֱדוֹם בְּיַד עַמִּי יִשְׂרָאֵל
instances.english_text: I will wreak My vengeance on Edom through My people Israel (lit. 'put my vengeance in Edom in the hand of My people Israel')
target: God’s use of Israel as the instrument of judgment on Edom
vehicle: placing an object (vengeance) into someone’s hand
hand as the organ of action and power
concrete transfer of a tool or weapon
ground: authored but mediated action is like putting a weapon in someone’s hand to wield
the 'hand' stands metonymically for active power and execution
vengeance conceptualized as a concrete implement of punishment
posture: assertive portrayal of Israel as God’s agent
emphasis on controlled, divinely directed violence
instances.explanation: The idiom of placing vengeance ‘in the hand’ of Israel treats vengeance as a transferable object and the hand as a metonym for agency, depicting Israel as the wielded instrument of divine retribution.

deliberation: Examined the language of vengeance and hatred. The notable figure is 'everlasting enmity', which hyperbolically characterizes the Philistine hostility as timeless, intensifying its severity.

instances.english_text: ancient hatred (lit. 'everlasting enmity')
target: the long-standing hostility of the Philistines toward Israel
ground: a very long, deep-rooted hatred is portrayed as if eternal
duration and intensity are exaggerated to convey implacability
association of 'forever' with unsurpassed continuity
instances.explanation: The phrase 'everlasting enmity' is hyperbolic, exaggerating the age and persistence of Philistine hatred to stress its depth and culpability.

deliberation: Identified the recurring anthropomorphic idiom 'stretch out my hand' as metaphorical. The phrase 'the remnant of the seacoast' uses 'seacoast' metonymically for the coastal population, so destroying this 'remnant' is a figurative way to speak of depopulating that region.

instances.english_text: I will stretch out My hand against the Philistines
target: God’s decisive action against the Philistines
vehicle: stretching out a hand toward an adversary
human gesture of striking or seizing
ground: both express intentional, forceful engagement against an enemy
human physical aggression used to conceptualize divine judgment
shared sense of directed power
instances.explanation: The expression depicts YHWH as a human combatant stretching out His hand to strike the Philistines, an anthropomorphic metaphor for divine judgment.

instances.english_text: and I will wipe out the last survivors of the seacoast
vehicle: territorial edge (coast) used to denote its people
ground: inhabitants are identified by the region they occupy
the coastal strip stands metonymically for its coastal population
link between landform and the people living on it
posture: prophetic doom on the coastal powers
instances.explanation: The phrase 'remnant of the seacoast' uses the coastal region metonymically for its surviving inhabitants, whose destruction is threatened.

deliberation: Considered whether 'great vengeance' and 'furious rebukes' are distinct images; they cluster around the same conceptual metaphor of vengeance as a concrete force inflicted. The idiom 'when I put my vengeance upon them' likewise treats vengeance as something placed on/into them, expressing judgment through object-transfer imagery.

instances.hebrew_text: וְעָשִׂיתִי בָם נְקָמוֹת גְּדֹלוֹת בְּתוֹכְחוֹת חֵמָה ... בְּתִתִּי אֶת־נִקְמָתִי בָּם
instances.english_text: I will wreak frightful [great] vengeance upon them by furious punishment; and when I inflict My vengeance upon them
target: the severe judgments God will bring on the Philistines
vehicle: vengeance as a 'great' thing executed and put upon them, with 'rebukes of wrath'
a heavy, concrete burden or blow inflicted on someone
ground: punishment is conceptualized as a tangible force or burden imposed on victims
intensity conveyed by describing vengeance as 'great' and 'furious'
shared sense of something forcefully laid upon a person
posture: prophetic emphasis on the terror of divine vengeance
instances.explanation: The verse depicts God’s vengeance as a great, furious thing that He actively executes and 'puts upon' them, treating retribution as a tangible force inflicted on the Philistines and heightening it with hyperbole.
